content: In the United States, the [Indian Citizenship Act](/wiki/Indian_Citizenship_Act "Indian Citizenship Act") was signed into law, recognizing U.S. citizenship for all indigenous Native Americans (referred to at the time as "[American Indians](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the United States")") who had been born within the United States and its territories, regardless of whether they had been granted citizenship by other means, such as service in the U.S. military or formal renunciation of tribal affiliation. At the time, there were 300,000 Native Americans in the U.S. out of a population that had been measured in 1920 as 106,021,537 people. Of the 300,000 there were 175,000 who had already been granted U.S. citizenship and the Act, signed by U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge"), extended full rights to the remaining 125,000 not already qualified.
sources: Peterson, Helen L. (May 1957). "American Indian Political Participation". *American Academy of Political and Social Science*. **311** (1): 116–121. [doi](/wiki/Doi_(identifier) "Doi (identifier)"):[10.1177/000271625731100113](https://doi.org/10.1177%2F000271625731100113). [S2CID](/wiki/S2CID_(identifier) "S2CID (identifier)") [144617127](https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:144617127).

content: In the Soviet Union, the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee selected the seven members of the *de facto* rulers of the nation, the Party's [Politburo](/wiki/Politburo_of_the_13th_Congress_of_the_All-Union_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks) "Politburo of the 13th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)"). To replace the vacancy left by the death of [Vladimir Lenin](/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin "Vladimir Lenin"), candidate member [Nikolai Bukharin](/wiki/Nikolai_Bukharin "Nikolai Bukharin") was elevated to full status, while full members [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin"), [Leon Trotsky](/wiki/Leon_Trotsky "Leon Trotsky"), [Alexei Rykov](/wiki/Alexei_Rykov "Alexei Rykov"), [Lev Kamenev](/wiki/Lev_Kamenev "Lev Kamenev"), [Mikhail Tomsky](/wiki/Mikhail_Tomsky "Mikhail Tomsky") and [Grigory Zinoviev](/wiki/Grigory_Zinoviev "Grigory Zinoviev") were re-elected.
U.S. President Coolidge also signed the [Revenue Act of 1924](/wiki/Revenue_Act_of_1924 "Revenue Act of 1924") into law, despite his many criticisms of the bill.
sources: "Criticizing Tax Measure, Coolidge Signs It". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 3, 1924. p. 1.

Sobel, Robert (1998). *Coolidge: An American Enigma*. Washington, D.C.: Regnery Publishing, Inc. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-59698-737-1](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59698-737-1 "Special:BookSources/978-1-59698-737-1").

The [Gila Wilderness](/wiki/Gila_Wilderness "Gila Wilderness"), which would become the first government-protected [wilderness](/wiki/Wilderness "Wilderness") area (defined as an area not significantly affected by human activity) in the world, was founded in the U.S. state of [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico") as the first wilderness area in the National Forest System. The designation followed the lobbying efforts of [Aldo Leopold](/wiki/Aldo_Leopold "Aldo Leopold"), the [United States Forest Service](/wiki/United_States_Forest_Service "United States Forest Service") supervisor of the [Carson National Forest](/wiki/Carson_National_Forest "Carson National Forest"), who proposed that the headwaters area of the [Gila River](/wiki/Gila_River "Gila River") should be preserved by an administrative process of excluding roads and denying use permits.

In [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania"), fighting was reported in [Shkodër](/wiki/Shkod%C3%ABr "Shkodër") and [Vlorë](/wiki/Vlor%C3%AB "Vlorë"), while an Italian destroyer arrived at the port of [Durrës](/wiki/Durr%C3%ABs "Durrës"). It was thought that Italy might intervene in the [June Revolution](/wiki/June_Revolution "June Revolution") if any Italian interests in Albania were threatened. Anti-government forces in [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania") took Shkodër the next day.
sources: Clayton, John (June 4, 1924). "Albania Rebels Rout Nationals, Seize Capital". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 12.
"Albanian Rebel Forces Win One Town; Lose One". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 5, 1924. p. 13.

[Indian](/wiki/India "India") physicist [Satyendra Nath Bose](/wiki/Satyendra_Nath_Bose "Satyendra Nath Bose") contacted [Albert Einstein](/wiki/Albert_Einstein "Albert Einstein") to report his development of what would become known as the [Bose–Einstein statistics](/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_statistics "Bose–Einstein statistics"). Bose mailed his short manuscript, *Planck's Law and the Light Quantum Hypothesis* to Einstein to get it published after the prestigious journal *[Philosophical Magazine](/wiki/Philosophical_Magazine "Philosophical Magazine")* rejected it. Einstein, recognizing the importance of the paper, translated it from [English](/wiki/English_language "English language") into [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") himself and submitted it on Bose's behalf to the prestigious *[Zeitschrift für Physik](/wiki/Zeitschrift_f%C3%BCr_Physik "Zeitschrift für Physik")*. Einstein would later apply Bose's principles on particles with mass and quickly predict the [Bose-Einstein condensate](/wiki/Bose-Einstein_condensate "Bose-Einstein condensate").

The [E.M. Forster](/wiki/E.M._Forster "E.M. Forster") novel *[A Passage to India](/wiki/A_Passage_to_India "A Passage to India")* was first published, originally by the British imprint [Edward Arnold](/wiki/Edward_Arnold_(publisher) "Edward Arnold (publisher)"). It would be published in the U.S. August 14, 1924, by [Harcourt, Brace and Company](/wiki/Harcourt_Brace "Harcourt Brace").
sources: ["The 100 best novels: No 47 – A Passage to India by EM Forster (1924)"](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/aug/18/100-best-novels-a-passage-to-india-em-forster-robert-mccrum). *[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")*. August 18, 2014. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: [Cyril Walker](/wiki/Cyril_Walker_(golfer) "Cyril Walker (golfer)") of England won the [U.S. Open](/wiki/1924_U.S._Open_(golf) "1924 U.S. Open (golf)") golf tournament by three strokes over [Bobby Jones](/wiki/Bobby_Jones_(golfer) "Bobby Jones (golfer)") of the U.S., at [Oakland Hills Country Club](/wiki/Oakland_Hills_Country_Club "Oakland Hills Country Club") in the [Detroit](/wiki/Detroit "Detroit") suburb of [Birmingham, Michigan](/wiki/Birmingham,_Michigan "Birmingham, Michigan").

content: The United States enacted the [Clarke–McNary Act](/wiki/Clarke%E2%80%93McNary_Act "Clarke–McNary Act"), facilitating the purchase of land to expand the [National Forest System](/wiki/National_forest_(United_States) "National forest (United States)"). On the same day, U.S. President Coolidge signed the [Anti-Heroin Act of 1924](/wiki/Anti-Heroin_Act_of_1924 "Anti-Heroin Act of 1924") and the [Oil Pollution Act of 1924](/wiki/Oil_Pollution_Act_of_1924 "Oil Pollution Act of 1924") into law.

British mountain climbers [George Mallory](/wiki/George_Mallory "George Mallory") and [Andrew "Sandy" Irvine](/wiki/Andrew_Irvine_(mountaineer) "Andrew Irvine (mountaineer)"), seeking to become the first persons to [climb to the top of the world's highest mountain](/wiki/1924_British_Mount_Everest_expedition "1924 British Mount Everest expedition"), [Mount Everest](/wiki/Mount_Everest "Mount Everest"), were last seen alive as [Noel Odell](/wiki/Noel_Odell "Noel Odell") watched the two men ascend from a base camp. For almost 75 years, no trace of either climber would be found until the discovery of Mallory's body on May 1, 1999, at an altitude of 26,760 feet (8,160 m).

The two unbeaten teams of the [Olympic soccer football championship](/wiki/Football_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1924 Summer Olympics"), [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football team") (4 wins, no draws or losses) faced [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland_national_football_team "Switzerland national football team") (3 wins, 1 draw, no losses) before 40,522 fans at the Olympic Stadium in [Colombes](/wiki/Colombes "Colombes"). Uruguay won, 3 to 0 for the championship and the gold medal.

[Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador") became the first nation in South America to extend the right to vote to women, after the lobbying of Dr. [Matilde Hidalgo](/wiki/Matilde_Hidalgo "Matilde Hidalgo"), as the Council of State of Ecuador ruled that Ecuadorian women enjoyed the right to elect and be elected ("Las mujeres ecuatorianas gozaban del derecho de elegir y ser elegidas.")

[1. F.C. Nuremberg](/wiki/1._FC_N%C3%BCrnberg "1. FC Nürnberg") beat [Hamburger SV](/wiki/Hamburger_SV "Hamburger SV"), 2 to 0, to win the [German football championship](/wiki/1924_German_football_championship "1924 German football championship").

content: [Giacomo Matteotti](/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti "Giacomo Matteotti"), a socialist member of the Italian Chamber of Deputies and one of [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini")'s most outspoken critics, was kidnapped in broad daylight. On May 30, he had spoken out against Prime Minister Mussolini and the Fascist movement in general. His fate would be a mystery until his body was found in August, with signs that he had been beaten to death. Six men were arrested for the crime, including [Amerigo Dumini](/wiki/Amerigo_Dumini "Amerigo Dumini"), who would confess a week later. Mussolini said he would order summary justice if any of the kidnappers were identified.
sources: Townley, Edward (2002). *Mussolini and Italy*. Oxford: [Heinemann Educational Publishers](/wiki/Heinemann_Educational_Publishers "Heinemann Educational Publishers"). p. 53. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-435-32725-9](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-435-32725-9 "Special:BookSources/0-435-32725-9").
Storer, John (June 14, 1924). "Kidnap Chief of Socialists in Italy; Dead?". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: The [Anglo-Iraqi Treaty of 1922](/wiki/Anglo-Iraqi_Treaty_of_1922 "Anglo-Iraqi Treaty of 1922"), making Iraq a self-governing British [protectorate](/wiki/Protectorate "Protectorate"), was ratified by the Iraqi Constituent Assembly by a vote of 36 to 25, with the United Kingdom having control of Iraq's foreign affairs and Iraq handling its own domestic affairs.
sources: "Iraq Treaty Ratified at Bagdad". *The Guardian*. Manchester. June 12, 1924. p. 8.

content: The [Republican National Convention](/wiki/1924_Republican_National_Convention "1924 Republican National Convention") opened in [Cleveland](/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland"), [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio").

**Died:** General [Salvador Alvarado](/wiki/Salvador_Alvarado "Salvador Alvarado"), 43, former Mexican Treasury Secretary and Governor of Yucatán, later an anti-government rebel, was killed by agents of Mexico's President Obregon.
sources: "Mexican Rebel Leader Killed by Own Men— Alvardo Arrested and Executed on Charge of Leading Troops to Disaster". *[Washington Evening Star](/wiki/Washington_Evening_Star "Washington Evening Star")*. June 14, 1924. p. 1.

content: [Alexandre Millerand](/wiki/Alexandre_Millerand "Alexandre Millerand"), [President of France](/wiki/President_of_France "President of France") since 1920, resigned after the triumph of the [Cartel des Gauches](/wiki/Cartel_des_Gauches "Cartel des Gauches") candidates in the [May elections for the Chamber of Deputies](/wiki/1924_French_legislative_election "1924 French legislative election").

Comedian and actor [Frank Tinney](/wiki/Frank_Tinney "Frank Tinney") was held to the grand jury on $25,000 bail over the assault charge brought by [Imogene Wilson](/wiki/Mary_Nolan "Mary Nolan"). Tinney denied ever striking her and made jokes on the witness stand despite admonitions from the bench.
sources: "Tinney Loses Court Bout to "Kis" Imogene". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 12, 1924. p. 13.

The largest train robbery in American history, based on adjusted value of the money taken, took place as the [Newton Gang](/wiki/Newton_Gang "Newton Gang") carried out the robbery of the express mail train number 57 of the [Milwaukee Road](/wiki/Milwaukee_Road "Milwaukee Road") (the [Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad](/wiki/Chicago,_Milwaukee_and_St._Paul_Railroad "Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad")) near [Rondout, Illinois](/wiki/Rondout,_Illinois "Rondout, Illinois"). The train was stopped by the robbers while it was carrying out its "[Fast Mail](/wiki/Fast_Mail_(MILW_train) "Fast Mail (MILW train)")" service. The amount of cash and bonds taken was more than three million dollars (similar to $54.3 million in 2024).
sources: United Press (June 13, 1924). ["Believe Huge Mail Robbery An Inside Job"](https://www.newspapers.com/clip/39523844/the_oshkosh_northwestern/). *The Oshkosh Northwestern*. Oshkosh, WI. p. 17 – via Newspapers.com.

content: Asphyxiation killed 44 crewmen aboard the [USS *Mississippi*](/wiki/USS_Mississippi_(BB-41) "USS Mississippi (BB-41)") off [San Pedro](/wiki/San_Pedro,_Los_Angeles "San Pedro, Los Angeles"), when the battleship's Number Two main battery turret exploded and filled the interior with smoke from a fire. A few minutes later, four rescuers were killed when the fire caused gunpowder in another cannon to explode. The explosion was, at the time, the deadliest peacetime disaster in U.S. Navy history.
sources: Shaffer, George (June 13, 1924). "Forty-Eight Die in 2 Blasts on U.S. Battleship". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: On the last day of the [Republican National Convention](/wiki/1924_Republican_National_Convention "1924 Republican National Convention"), U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge") was formally nominated as the Republican candidate for the 1924 U.S. presidential election, receiving the votes of all but 44 delegates. Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin received 44 votes of delegates from Wisconsin and North Dakota, and Hiram Johnson of California got 10 delegate votes from South Dakota. [Charles G. Dawes](/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes "Charles G. Dawes") won the Republican nomination for vice president to be Coolidge's running mate.
sources: "Coolidge and Dawes Named". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 13, 1924. p. 1.

content: [Gaston Doumergue](/wiki/Gaston_Doumergue "Gaston Doumergue") was sworn in as the 13th [President of France](/wiki/President_of_France "President of France"), succeeding Alexandre Millerand.

U.S. Army Lieutenant [John A. Macready](/wiki/John_A._Macready "John A. Macready") At McCook, he also became the first airplane pilot to successfully bail out of a stricken aircraft at night. Macready was approaching McCook Field at Dayton, Ohio, when the engine died. Unable to see a site for an emergency landing, Macready parachuted from his plane and was able to survive after landing in a tree.

The [oratorio](/wiki/Oratorio "Oratorio") *[Le Laudi](/wiki/Le_Laudi "Le Laudi")*, written by Swiss composer [Hermann Suter](/wiki/Hermann_Suter "Hermann Suter"), was performed for the first time, premiering at [Basel](/wiki/Basel "Basel") to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Basel Choral Society.

The [International Football Association Board](/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board "International Football Association Board") legalized the scoring of a goal by [corner kick](/wiki/Corner_kick "Corner kick") in advance of the 1924 Summer Olympics competition. The first score by corner kick in international play would be made on October 2, 1924, by [Cesáreo Onzari](/wiki/Ces%C3%A1reo_Onzari "Cesáreo Onzari") of the [Argentina national football team](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team") in 2 to 1 win over the Olympic champion [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football team"), and the goal was called "an Olympico" as a result.
sources: ["International Football Association Board Minutes of the Annual Meeting Held on Saturday, 14th June 1924"](https://web.archive.org/web/20110616011341/http://ssbra.org/html/laws/IFABarc/pdf/1924/1924min.pdf) (PDF). London: SSBRA. 14 June 1924. p. 3. Archived from [the original](http://ssbra.org/html/laws/IFABarc/pdf/1924/1924min.pdf) (PDF) on 16 June 2011. Retrieved 29 November 2009.

content: [Aldo Finzi](/wiki/Aldo_Finzi_(politician) "Aldo Finzi (politician)") resigned as Italy's Under Secretary of State over the [Matteotti](/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti "Giacomo Matteotti") disappearance, explaining he was doing so in order to defend himself from "libelous accusations" spread against him by the opposition. Rome's Chief of Police, [Emilio De Bono](/wiki/Emilio_De_Bono "Emilio De Bono"), resigned three days later.
sources: "Minister Quits in Kidnapping of Italian Deputy". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 15, 1924. p. 1.
Storer, John (June 18, 1924). "Cabinet Quits as Scandal in Italy Grows". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: The [Lone Scouts of America](/wiki/Lone_Scouts_of_America "Lone Scouts of America"), founded in 1915 by newspaper publisher [W. D Boyce](/wiki/William_D._Boyce "William D. Boyce") as a rural version of the Boy Scouts, merged with the [Boy Scouts of America](/wiki/Boy_Scouts_of_America "Boy Scouts of America") and discontinued operations.
sources: Petterchak, Janice A. (2003). *Lone Scout: W. D. Boyce and American Boy Scouting*. Legacy Press. p. 117.

content: [Fan Noli](/wiki/Fan_Noli "Fan Noli") (Theofan Stilian Noli), one of the leaders of Albania's [June Revolution](/wiki/June_Revolution "June Revolution"), formed a government of ministers with himself as Prime Minister of Albania.

King [Victor Emmanuel III of Italy](/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III_of_Italy "Victor Emmanuel III of Italy") held an extraordinary council with former Prime Ministers and members of the royal family to discuss the Matteotti crisis as [Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini")'s hold on power appeared increasingly tenuous. Italian Fascist politician [Cesare Rossi](/wiki/Cesare_Rossi_(politician) "Cesare Rossi (politician)") surrendered to police the same day after having been in hiding. Another Fascist, [Giovanni Marinelli](/wiki/Giovanni_Marinelli "Giovanni Marinelli"), was arrested three days later.
sources: Wales, Henry (June 17, 1924). "Dictator of Italy Totters". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

[Sachar, Howard M.](/wiki/Howard_Sachar "Howard Sachar") (2015). *The Assassination of Europe, 1918–1942: A Political History*. content: The much-delayed trial of [Mabel Normand](/wiki/Mabel_Normand "Mabel Normand")'s chauffeur, over the New Year's Day shooting of millionaire Courtland S. Dines, opened in Los Angeles. [Edna Purviance](/wiki/Edna_Purviance "Edna Purviance") once again testified that she was out of the room when the shooting happened.
sources: Shaffer, George (June 17, 1924). "Dines a Stingy Host When it Came to Attire". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 6.

content: Finnish athlete [Paavo Nurmi](/wiki/Paavo_Nurmi "Paavo Nurmi") broke two world records on the same day at a meet at [Eläintarha Stadium](/wiki/El%C3%A4intarha_Stadium "Eläintarha Stadium") in [Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"), running the 1500 meters in 3 minutes, 52.6 seconds, and later winning the 5000 meters in 14 minutes, 28.2 seconds.

[Mabel Normand](/wiki/Mabel_Normand "Mabel Normand")'s chauffeur was acquitted on the assault charge from the New Year's Day shooting, though he was immediately re-arrested on a separate liquor charge. Despite the acquittal, the scandal was too much for Normand's film career after the [William Desmond Taylor](/wiki/William_Desmond_Taylor "William Desmond Taylor") murder and she was effectively finished as a Hollywood star.

content: Sir [Francis Younghusband](/wiki/Francis_Younghusband "Francis Younghusband") of the [Royal Geographical Society](/wiki/Royal_Geographical_Society "Royal Geographical Society") sent a telegram informing the media that [George Mallory](/wiki/George_Mallory "George Mallory") and [A.C. Irvine](/wiki/Andrew_Irvine_(mountaineer) "Andrew Irvine (mountaineer)") had died attempting to [climb Mount Everest](/wiki/1924_British_Mount_Everest_expedition "1924 British Mount Everest expedition").

content: The ballet *[Le Train Bleu](/wiki/Le_Train_Bleu_(ballet) "Le Train Bleu (ballet)")*, choreographed by [Bronislava Nijinska](/wiki/Bronislava_Nijinska "Bronislava Nijinska"), with music by [Darius Milhaud](/wiki/Darius_Milhaud "Darius Milhaud"), was performed for the first time, premiering in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") at the [Théâtre des Champs-Élysées](/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_des_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es "Théâtre des Champs-Élysées").

[Steve Sullivan](/wiki/Steve_Sullivan_(boxer) "Steve Sullivan (boxer)") won the world junior lightweight boxing title by defeating titleholder [Johnny Dundee](/wiki/Johnny_Dundee "Johnny Dundee") in a bout at Brooklyn.

content: Murder suspect [Fritz Haarmann](/wiki/Fritz_Haarmann "Fritz Haarmann") was arrested in [Hanover](/wiki/Hanover "Hanover"), Germany, after he was seen stalking boys at the Central Station. A search of his apartment turned up bloodstains and possessions of victims as one of the most notorious serial killers in German history was revealed.
sources: Parker, R.J. (29 September 2017). *Serial Killers Abridged: : 100 Serial Killers*. Createspace. p. 100. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-4947-7216-1](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4947-7216-1 "Special:BookSources/978-1-4947-7216-1").

content: U.S. Army First Lieutenant [Russell Maughan](/wiki/Russell_Maughan "Russell Maughan") successfully made the first [dawn-to-dusk transcontinental flight across the United States](/wiki/Dawn-to-dusk_transcontinental_flight_across_the_United_States "Dawn-to-dusk transcontinental flight across the United States"), landing at [Crissy Field](/wiki/Crissy_Field "Crissy Field") in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") at 9:46 in the evening local time, one minute before sundown, after having departed earlier on the same day from [Mitchel Field](/wiki/Mitchel_Field "Mitchel Field") on Long Island near [Garden City, New York](/wiki/Garden_City,_New_York "Garden City, New York") at 3:58 in the morning local time. During his flight of 20 hours and 48 minutes, in a [Curtiss P-1 Hawk](/wiki/Curtiss_P-1_Hawk "Curtiss P-1 Hawk"), he made refueling stops at [Dayton, Ohio](/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio "Dayton, Ohio"); [St. Joseph, Missouri](/wiki/St._Joseph,_Missouri "St. Joseph, Missouri"); [North Platte, Nebraska](/wiki/North_Platte,_Nebraska "North Platte, Nebraska"); [Cheyenne, Wyoming](/wiki/Cheyenne,_Wyoming "Cheyenne, Wyoming") and the [Bonneville Salt Flats](/wiki/Bonneville_Salt_Flats "Bonneville Salt Flats") at [Salduro, Utah](/wiki/Salduro,_Utah "Salduro, Utah") before completing a journey of 2,670 miles (4,300 km).
sources: "Flies Across U.S.; 18 Hours". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 24, 1924. p. 1.
"Flies Across U.S.; 18 Hours". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. June 24, 1924. p. 1.

content: German serial killer [Fritz Haarmann](/wiki/Fritz_Haarmann "Fritz Haarmann"), called the Butcher of Hanover, was arrested eight days after murdering and dismembering his final victim, Erich de Vries. Haarmann was implicated by another teenager who had been arrested at Hanover station the night before. Tried and convicted on 24 of 27 charges of murder, Haarmann would be beheaded on April 15, 1925.
sources: Lessing, Thomas; Berg, Karl; God, George (1993). *Monsters of Weimar*. Berlin, Germany: Nemesis Publications. pp. 61–62. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [1-897743-10-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-897743-10-6 "Special:BookSources/1-897743-10-6").

[Attorney General](/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Ireland "Attorney General of Ireland") [Hugh Kennedy](/wiki/Hugh_Kennedy_(judge) "Hugh Kennedy (judge)") took office as the first [Chief Justice of Ireland](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Ireland#List_of_chief_justices "Chief Justice of Ireland"), presiding over the [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ireland "Supreme Court of Ireland") of the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State").

content: The [Democratic National Convention](/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention "1924 Democratic National Convention") opened at [Madison Square Garden](/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1890) "Madison Square Garden (1890)") in New York City. Former Treasury Secretary [William Gibbs McAdoo](/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo "William Gibbs McAdoo") was considered the [front-runner](/wiki/Front-runner "Front-runner") going into the convention, but required two-thirds of the 1,092 delegate votes for a majority. The convention would last 16 days before a nominee would be picked on July 9.
sources: Henning, Arthur Sears (June 20, 1924). "It is McAdoo vs. the Field". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

Murray, Robert K. (1976). [*The 103rd Ballot: Democrats and the Disaster in Madison Square Garden*](https://archive.org/details/103rdballotdemoc0000murr). New York: Harper & Row. content: The brand name for [Kleenex](/wiki/Kleenex "Kleenex"), which would become synonymous with [facial tissue](/wiki/Facial_tissue "Facial tissue"), was used for the first time in commerce, according to an application for registered trademark filed with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) by the original manufacturer, the Cellucotton Products Company of [Neenah, Wisconsin](/wiki/Neenah,_Wisconsin "Neenah, Wisconsin").

The Italian Senate held a ceremony commemorating [Giacomo Matteotti](/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti "Giacomo Matteotti"), now presumed dead. [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") promised to reform his government and then put it to a vote of confidence the last week of July, but said that the Fascists did not need to be removed from power over the crisis.
sources: [Sachar, Howard M.](/wiki/Howard_Sachar "Howard Sachar") (2015). *The Assassination of Europe, 1918–1942: A Political History*. content: The *[New York Daily Mirror](/wiki/New_York_Daily_Mirror "New York Daily Mirror")* was launched by publisher [William Randolph Hearst](/wiki/William_Randolph_Hearst "William Randolph Hearst") as a morning paper in New York City, to compete against the popular *[New York Daily News](/wiki/New_York_Daily_News "New York Daily News")*. Hearst, who already owned the morning *New York American* and the *New York Evening Journal*, would sell the *Daily Mirror* in 1928 and then buy it back in 1932; the paper would continue publication until October 16, 1963.

The "[Aventine Secession](/wiki/Aventine_Secession_(20th_century) "Aventine Secession (20th century)")" took place as 123 members of the opposition in the [Italian Chamber of Deputies](/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Kingdom_of_Italy) "Chamber of Deputies (Kingdom of Italy)") walked out of the Chamber, retreated to [Aventine Hill](/wiki/Aventine_Hill "Aventine Hill") and gave Premier [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") an ultimatum. The Deputies demanded an acknowledgment of government responsibility for Fascist crimes, a complete and thorough investigation of the Matteotti affair and the abolition of the [Blackshirts](/wiki/Milizia_Volontaria_per_la_Sicurezza_Nazionale "Milizia Volontaria per la Sicurezza Nazionale"). If the government did not accede, the ultimatum read, the opposition would stage a boycott of parliament. On the same day, 10 minutes of silence were observed all over Italy in respect for [Giacomo Matteotti](/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti "Giacomo Matteotti"). Ultimately, the strategy of the 123 legislators would backfire and they would be declared on November 9, 1926, to have forfeited their seats, clearing the way legally for Italy to become a one-party state under Fascist control.
sources: Sheean, Vincent (June 27, 1924). "Deputies Serve Ultimatum on Italy Premier". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.
Sheean, Vincent (June 28, 1924). "Italy Prays for Matteotti as Cabinet Alters". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 12.

A tornado [killed 85 people](/wiki/1924_Lorain%E2%80%93Sandusky_tornado "1924 Lorain–Sandusky tornado") in the U.S. state of [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio"), 72 of them in [Lorain, Ohio](/wiki/Lorain,_Ohio "Lorain, Ohio") (including 15 inside a theater and eight inside a bath house on Lake Erie), after starting off the coast of [Sandusky](/wiki/Sandusky,_Ohio "Sandusky, Ohio"), where it killed eight people.
sources: ["Hundreds Killed by Tornado in Ohio; 80 in Lorain Theatre"](https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/06/29/101603761.pdf?pdf_redirect=true&ip=0) (PDF). *New York Times*. New York Times. June 29, 1924. Retrieved 6 May 2020.

content: At the [Democratic National Convention](/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention "1924 Democratic National Convention"), a plank calling for participation in the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") was soundly rejected by a margin of 742½ to 353½. A plank denouncing the [Ku Klux Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku Klux Klan") by name was also narrowly rejected.

[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico")'s President [Álvaro Obregón](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n "Álvaro Obregón") announced that he was suspending further payments from the Mexican Treasury to the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico (ICBM), abrogating the [De la Huerta–Lamont Treaty](/wiki/De_la_Huerta%E2%80%93Lamont_Treaty "De la Huerta–Lamont Treaty") that had been signed on June 16, 1922. Mexico had paid $16,250,000 to the ICBM Bankers in 1922 and 1923.

After the first day of balloting and 15 rounds of voting, and no candidate receiving the necessary 729 votes for a two-thirds majority, the [Democratic National Convention](/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention "1924 Democratic National Convention") adjourned at midnight. [William Gibbs McAdoo](/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo "William Gibbs McAdoo") (with 479 votes) and [Al Smith](/wiki/Al_Smith "Al Smith") (with 305.5) were deadlocked in balloting. On the first ballot, McAdoo had 431.5 and Smith 241, with the eventual nominee in seventh place with 31.
sources: Henning, Arthur Sears (July 1, 1924). "Deadlock After 15 Ballots". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

Sixteen-year-old Calvin Coolidge Jr. played a tennis match on the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House") tennis court wearing tennis shoes but no socks. During the course of the match he developed a toe blister that would lead to fatal [blood poisoning](/wiki/Blood_poisoning "Blood poisoning").
sources: Mikkelson, Barbara and David (June 12, 2014). ["Too Young to Dye"](http://www.snopes.com/horrors/poison/coolidge.asp). *[Snopes](/wiki/Snopes "Snopes")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: Dutch-born Jewish poet [Jacob Israël de Haan](/wiki/Jacob_Isra%C3%ABl_de_Haan "Jacob Israël de Haan") was assassinated in Jerusalem by the [Avraham Tehomi](/wiki/Avraham_Tehomi "Avraham Tehomi") on the orders of [Haganah](/wiki/Haganah "Haganah") leader [Yitzhak Ben-Zvi](/wiki/Yitzhak_Ben-Zvi "Yitzhak Ben-Zvi") for his anti-Zionist activity and contacts with Arab leaders. Tehomi waited outside of the Shaare Zedek Hospital for De Haan, then shot him three times.
sources: Shlomo Nakdimon; Shaul Mayzlish (1985). *Deh Han : ha-retsah ha-politi ha-rishon be-Erets Yisraʼel / De Haan: The first political assassination in Palestine* (in Hebrew) (1st ed.). Tel Aviv: Modan Press. [OCLC](/wiki/OCLC_(identifier) "OCLC (identifier)") [21528172](https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/21528172).

Green, David B. (30 June 2013). ["This Day in Jewish History / Zionism's First Political Assassination"](https://www.haaretz.com/jewish/.premium-this-day-zionism-s-first-political-assassination-1.5288744). *Haaretz*. Retrieved 8 March 2021.
